            I am an ecologist interested in drivers of
            biodiversity, community structure, and ecosystem function in
            a constantly changing world. I combine theory
            driven experiments, observational fieldwork, and
            quantitative syntheses primarily working in marine coastal
            ecosystems but am interested in comparing patterns across
            ecosystems and taxa to search for general theory. I recently
            finished my PhD at Stanford University working with Dr. Fiorenza
            Micheli and will begin a post-doctoral fellow position
            in the fall of 2023 with Dr. Deron
            Burkepile at UC Santa Barbara.
            PhD Biology, Stanford University, 2023
            MSc Biology, University of Victoria, 2017
            BScH Biology, Queen’s University, 2013

articles.title: Outreach
articles.contents:
Linked with both my research and teaching experiences, I’m committed to furthering diversity, equity and inclusion within academia. I helped co-create and run the Stanford Biology PhD Preview Program, which helps prospective students nagivate the application process and leverage their strengths within their applications. I also worked on the DIMES Network (Diversifying and Integrating Marine Education at Stations) where we created an ecology field curriculum for undergraduate students along with existing virutal field trips to increase access to coastal field stations.
In addition, I have written about my research for various blog posts (HMS High Tidings, ICRS Reefbites Feature Friday) and have interacted with the public on World Ocean’s Day as a scientific diver and at the Hopkins Marine Station running the surfgrass touch tank.


Showing students from the Middlebury Institute of International Studies my field experiment in Big Sur, California; Photo Credit: Meghan McKenna

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
My research interests fit within three broad themes that often overlap and interact:
I) Trophic interactions structuring communities
I’m interested in how consumers (e.g., predators, herbivores) influence how communities look and function. I have assessed how large fishes affect coral reefs through field experiments and data-syntheses. In this work, I evaluated how large fishes structure coral recruitment, community variability and turnover, and if there are cascading trophic interactions down from large predators to coral reef recovery. In addition, I evaluated how the arrival timing of consumers influences recovery trajectories by conducting a field experiment in the rocky intertidal.


Experiment in the Chagos Archipelago, Photo Credit: Kristina Tietjen


II) Biodiversity patterns and consequences of biodiversity change
In addition, I’m interested in how biodiversity patterns vary through space and time and what are the consequences of biodiversity change. I’ve previously evaluated congruence in coral reef diversity patterns (McDevitt-Irwin et al. 2021), the influence of wave exposure on coral reef recovery dynamics (Lange et al. 2021), and how fishing and habitat influence herbivorous fish grazing (Robinson et al. 2019).


JMI conducting benthic surveys, Photo Credit: Guy Stevens

III) Global and local stressors altering communities
My research also focuses on how global and local stressors are currently altering communities around the world. I’ve typically approached this research on coral reef ecosystems, at both the micro and macro scale. I’ve evaluated how both local human disturbances and El Nino events influence the coral microbiome (McDevitt-Irwin et al. 2018, McDevitt-Irwin et al. 2019, Claar et al. 2020) and how heat stress events influence coral reef resilience and bleaching patterns (Claar et al. 2018, Baum et al. 2023).


JMI collecting a coral tissue sample, Photo Credit: Kristina Tietjen

articles.contents:
I am committed to learning and growing as an instructor and have taken various courses on course development and how to be an inclusive and effective teacher to diverse students (e.g. Inclusive and Effective Teaching, Science and Engineering Course Design). In addition I shadowed a professor at West Valley Community College through the Preparing Future Professors program.
